“Did you hear Marfa Petrovna is gone?” Raskolnikov cut in, a bit harshly.

“Oh, you’ve heard that too? Of course you have…” The guy seemed uneasy. “Honestly, I don’t know what to say. My conscience is clear, though. I’m not worried about it. Everything was legit—the doctors said it was apoplexy from bathing right after a big meal and a bottle of wine. Nothing else it could be. But here’s what I’ve been thinking on my train ride here: did I somehow cause that… disaster? Maybe I irritated her or something. But I decided that’s not really the case.”

Raskolnikov chuckled. “Why do you even care?”

“What’s so funny? Look, I only hit her twice with a switch—no marks or anything. Don’t think I’m a jerk; I know it was terrible. But honestly, I’m pretty sure Marfa Petrovna actually liked my ‘enthusiasm.’ Your sister’s drama had drained her; she’d been stuck at home for days with nothing to show off. Plus, she bored everyone with that letter (yeah, the one she read out loud). Then, out of nowhere, those two hits came down! First thing she did was call for the carriage…”

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Raskolnikov reflects on the moral implications of his actions and the nature of human relationships, questioning whether he contributed to a calamity.
